identifier-syntax.description:
A PRONOM Unique Identifier (PUID) is composed of two elements, the PUID type, and the actual identifier. The PUID type identifies the class of representation information to which the identifier refers, where each identifier is unique within that class. Thus, both elements are required to construct a unique identifier.
The syntax may be expressed in formal BNF notation as follows:
<puid> ::= <puid_type> '/' <identifier>
<puid_type> ::= 'fmt'
<identifier> ::= <fragment> | <identifier> <fragment>
<fragment> ::= <digit> | <letter>
<letter> ::= 'a' â€“ 'z'
<digit> ::= '0' - '9'
The PUID type is expressed as a lowercase alphanumeric string. The only PUID type currently defined is "fmt", which denotes that the identifier relates to a file format. Other types may be defined in the future. The identifier itself is expressed as a lowercase alphanumeric string of arbitrary length. The PUID type and identifier are separated by a forward slash.

identifier-normalization.description: The PUID type is case sensitive and must be normalised to lower case.

namespace-information.description: The PUID namespace consists of identifiers which correspond to entries in the PRONOM technical registry. Every identifier is unique within the namespace, and is persistently and unambiguously bound to a single registry entry. The PUID type element identifies the type of registry entry (e.g. a file format), and the identifier element denotes an instance of that type within the registry (e.g. the record for a specific file format).
